A statistical downscaling technique termed Analogues was introduced by ref. 29. The key idea is to represent regional climate variables as a function of the large-scale atmospheric conditions (which is the rationale behind downscaling). For that, large-scale weather patterns for a given day are compared to high-resolution observation or reanalysis data, and time periods with the most similar circulation patterns (analogues) are selected. The observed weather at these times then serves as input to estimate the high-resolution climate state, assuming statistical stationarity. The technique can, for instance, be useful for statistical downscaling purposes or for paleoclimate reconstructions, but also for attribution of extreme events30. In the latter case, the difference between the analogue-estimated state and the actual state represents the thermodynamic component of climate change, relative to the reference period. For example, ref. 31 used the method to demonstrate that the cold European winter of 2010 was less cold than it would otherwise have been, because of anthropogenic warming.

Another statistical method of event attribution is termed Dynamical Adjustment. The method removes dynamical variations in a time series of a target variable, for instance by using empirical orthogonal functions, weather pattern clustering or linear regression, so that the anthropogenic climate change signal becomes more distinct32,33. The implicit assumption, as with storyline attribution, is that long-term dynamical variations are best regarded as internal variability. Rather than targeting a particular extreme event (as with Analogues), long-term trends are adjusted, although the decomposition can of course be examined for a particular event to provide an event attribution. Ref. 34 demonstrate the potential of dynamical adjustment as an attribution method for extreme events using the European cold spell and the Russian heat wave of 2010 as examples.

In regional climate modelling, a technique called Pseudo Global Warming (PGW) to study climate change effects on extreme events was presented by Ref. 35. It calculates climate change differences between global model simulations of e.g., present-day and pre-industrial climate or between future and present-day climate for important meteorological variables such as temperature, pressure, wind and humidity. These differences are then added to reanalysis data and constitute the PGW input data as modified boundary data for the regional climate model so that high-resolution simulations for the extreme event can be simulated for different climate states. The method is quite similar to spectrally nudged storylines, the difference is in its application being limited to regional studies and in not applying spectral nudging throughout the model domain. Although mainly used to study changes in climate, some studies have used PGW for attributing extremes to anthropogenic climate change, for instance, precipitation events over Asia36 or typhoon-induced extreme precipitation37.

Another model-based event attribution method is to use short-term weather forecasts of the event, which are re-simulated under counter-factual conditions. Since the dynamical conditioning only occurs via the initial conditions, it weakens with forecast lead time because of the spread in the forecast ensembles through the butterfly effect. This leads to a temporal non-stationarity in the degree of conditioning as well as from spin-up of the climate response during the forecast, which complicates the statistical analysis38. Moreover, the dynamical conditioning is only effective for weather forecast timescales of a few days to a week, where the main anthropogenic effect comes from the counter-factual SSTs38. Hence the method has mainly been used for tropical cyclones39, showing in particular that the rainfall was increased by anthropogenic climate change. Since the probability of the initial conditions is not assessed, it is still a conditional attribution. Another conditional attribution using a regional-model ensemble weather-hindcasting approach analysed the Colorado floods of September 2013, showing that anthropogenic drivers increased the magnitude of heavy precipitation40.

Compared to the other model-based approaches, global spectrally nudged storylines have the key advantage of providing model fields that are both spatially and temporally statistically homogeneous, making the statistical analysis much simpler, at the cost of not necessarily being able to follow small-scale extreme events.

A new approach which is very similar in spirit to spectrally nudged storylines is to use a simple data assimilation system rather than spectral nudging to constrain the atmospheric state41. In this approach, the only atmospheric field assimilated is sea level pressure, which is combined with either factual or counter-factual SSTs. The method appears to be very effective for analysis of storms, and can be applied to historical storms in the distant past provided surface pressure observations are available. Thus, rather than asking how a recent extreme event would have been in the past, this method is able to ask how an extreme event from the distant past would be today. We do not include this method in Table 3 since there is not yet sufficient literature.

Impact-based studies applying spectrally nudged storylines

A new task for spectrally nudged storylines is to move forward from attribution of hazards to attribution of their impacts. So far, only a small number of such studies have been published. One of them is a storyline study on Hurricane Sandy’s impact on New York City42, which assessed how sea-level rise and changes in storm features affected coastal flooding impacts on critical infrastructure. To account for some degree of internal variability, the hurricane was altered in its landfall position, intensity and shape. It was found that even moderate increases in sea level and changes in storm tracks can affect flood impacts. A strength of this study is the simulation of the compound flooding effect of storm surge, high tide, sea level rise and extreme precipitation which caused the hurricane’s impact on critical infrastructure. Through their specificity, storylines can provide a more advanced insight into the interaction of these drivers under past and future climate conditions.

Heat waves can lead to droughts, wildfires or crop failures. Extremely dangerous is the impact of heat on human mortality. This impact was assessed by ref. 43 for Germany. The aim was to predict the heat-related mortality for different future climate states based on storylines using advanced machine learning techniques. The storylines’ factual and future climate data relies on observed extreme events and shows how their impact on mortality may change if these events would happen in a warmer world. This is one of the first studies to combine machine learning with spectrally nudged storylines to attribute extreme event impacts. Neural networks are well suited and often superior to conventional statistical analysis in finding complex nonlinear relationships between extremes and variables such as mortality, provided that the underlying data basis is sufficiently large and of high quality. However, the machine learning model assumes that the climate-mortality relationship is not changing due to external factors in different climates, which may not be realistic in the far future.

In 2012, a large crop loss for soybeans, which even affected global food markets, occurred in the three largest soybean producing regions in the United States, Brazil, and Argentina due to compound hot and dry weather conditions. Ref. 44 examined the impact of climate change on soybean production for this extreme drought year using a statistical crop model combined with global storyline data. The study found that drought intensity did not change between the storylines, but higher temperatures and an intensified temperature-moisture interaction will lead to larger crop losses in the future. Applying such crop models to climate storylines may improve adaptation to climate change and communication with decision makers by identifying regions that are most vulnerable to anthropogenic climate change, e.g., where more irrigation or a change in crop type is needed.

Ref. 45 investigated near-surface ozone pollution levels in warmer climates, which would have health implications for humans and ecosystems. Storyline scenarios of air pollution were developed using a global atmospheric chemistry model to assess ozone pollution extremes in a warmer climate. The results point to two competing processes, which are dependent on the level of warming: vegetation and local photochemistry increase ozone extremes, while a concurrent moistening of the atmosphere leads to lower ozone concentrations. Such highly complex interrelating processes could well have been missed in a purely probabilistic attribution study, emphasizing the value of adding the storyline method in a combined attribution approach.

Outlook

Spectrally nudged storylines bring together the concepts of global climate downscaling (spectral nudging) and conditional attribution (storylines) to provide a methodology to predict surface climate from large-scale atmospheric circulation together with thermodynamic forcings, with the details filled in by the climate model. The methodology is easy to implement and easy to interpret, whilst respecting the complexity of a local situation, and thus exemplifies the key principles of “Small is Beautiful”46. We conclude this piece by reflecting on how spectrally nudged storylines can contribute to the changing face of climate science.

Impact attribution

There is a rapidly growing demand for attribution of climate impacts, yet this inevitably involves multiple causal factors, not just climate change. It is highly misleading if disasters are attributed solely to climate change, even if climate change increased their likelihood. In order to go from hazards to impacts for particular events, specific causation is needed: general causation is not sufficient47. Spectrally nudged storylines have the potential to fill this gap, as the few existing studies already show. What is needed is the inclusion of impact models with realistic intervention points, so that counterfactuals in the decision space can be combined with climate counterfactuals. Digital twins48 offer promise in this respect.

Unseen events

Risk management requires examining things that might have happened (so-called ‘downward counterfactuals’) rather than just those that did happen. There is rapidly growing work in this space, either mining large ensemble simulations49, or boosting ensemble members to create extremes that are more extreme than those observed50. This is very much in the spirit of ‘tales of future weather’51, but for the present. Such unseen events could be used to spectrally nudge higher resolution climate models and propagate the events through to impacts.

Dynamical aspects of climate change

A long-recognized limitation of the storyline approach to event attribution is its inability to account for possible changes in atmospheric circulation. This has been justified by the importance of quantifying the robust aspects of climate change, given the ambiguity of predicted circulation changes from climate models at the regional scale. However, circulation changes are beginning to emerge in the ever-lengthening observed record, and very often, they lie outside the range of changes predicted by the climate models, even after accounting for internal variability52. This raises the question of whether storylines of circulation change based on observations might be more useful than those based on the climate models themselves53. Spectral nudging using these observed circulation trends could be used to expand the range of explanatory factors considered in event storylines.

Bridging between specific and general causation

Both specific (storyline) and general (probabilistic) attribution have their purposes, and their strengths and weaknesses. Given the widespread prevalence of probabilistic event attribution and its planned operationalization, it is important to be able to connect the two approaches, and connect them both to attribution of changes in the statistics of extreme events, as reflected in aggregations over many events (and as discussed, e.g., in IPCC Assessment Reports). Because global spectrally nudged storylines are not event-specific but include all events worldwide during the simulation period, collections of events can be analysed, as with the attribution of a single hurricane season by aggregating over all forecasted hurricanes using the short-term forecast method54. This would also help connect attribution of historical events to long-term trends and future risk.

Global km-scale modelling

There is a growing push for the use of km-scale atmospheric models in order to explicitly model atmospheric convection, which is important for extreme events such as heavy precipitation55. Such models are very computationally expensive to run, however, which effectively precludes their use in probabilistic attribution. Any short simulation is necessarily conditional on the large-scale conditions. As already mentioned, spectral nudging provides an interpretable conditionality so that the short simulations can be more effectively compared against observations, and used for event attribution.

Artificial Intelligence (AI)

AI could further enhance the potential of climate storylines. In their recent study, Ref. 56 assess an AI-based weather and climate model in simulating extreme heat waves. They show that the model can realistically reproduce such events in different climate states. However, the study also points to a limiting factor. In comparison to physics-based models the AI-model tends to underestimate future warming. As a reason for this the authors suggest the absence of land-atmosphere feedbacks in the AI-based model. Perturbing AI-based models (analogously to how spectrally nudged AGCMs are perturbed with SSTs) has been shown to produce physically realistic responses in some AI-based weather models57. For application to extreme event attribution, AI is very well suited not just for detection and attribution of extreme events, but also for the detection of nonlinear relationships and drivers of extremes58. New AI attribution methods are currently explored in the EU-funded projects Climate Intelligence (CLINT, https://climateintelligence.eu/) and eXtreme events: Artificial Intelligence for Detection and Attribution (XAIDA, https://xaida.eu/) which already show promising results into the direction of combining AI and storyline attribution to result in a common attribution framework.

urn:contentItem:6CPM-7DX1-F03F-K4BM-00000-00Typhoon hits northern Japan, paralyzing airplane and train traffic2024-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:23:07ZLexisNexisAIRLINE INDUSTRY NEWS, Weather news, Natural disasters news, Asia-Pacific latest & JAPAN NEWSTyphoon hits northern Japan, paralyzing airplane and train trafficMaria Kholina

A large tropical typhoon Maria has significantly disrupted transportation in the Iwate Prefecture and other areas in northeastern Japan. 86 flights were canceled today, most of which typically connect the Tohoku region with Tokyo and Osaka, citing NHK.

Japan Airlines canceled 78 flights, while Nippon Airways canceled an additional 8. The number of canceled flights is expected to increase.

Rail transport in the prefecture has also faced significant disruptions. Although the national high-speed rail lines Tohoku Shinkansen, Yamagata Shinkansen, and Akita Shinkansen are still operating, JR East warns of possible delays and cancellations. Local rail lines have already partially halted operations today.

Japanese highway operators are also warning of possible closures on some sections of expressways due to heavy rain and the risk of flooding.

Meteorologists predict that the typhoon will bring a record amount of rainfall, potentially leading to landslides, flooding, and other natural disasters. They recommend that residents and tourists planning trips to or from the region closely monitor updates on the situation.

Typhoons are a common issue in Japan. Experts say the risk of such meteorological events is usually highest in summer and early autumn.

One of the most devastating typhoons in Japan occurred in 2019. Typhoon Hagibis damaged infrastructure and residential buildings, causing catastrophic destruction across much of eastern Japan.

Recently, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida canceled his trip to Asian countries due to the threat of an earthquake in Japan.

urn:contentItem:6FBF-MKP3-RRNF-74ND-00000-00Tokyo braced for earthquakes and typhoons as city evolves into disaster-proof metropolis2025-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:23:07ZLexisNexisTokyo braced for earthquakes and typhoons as city evolves into disaster-proof metropolisBy, Kelly Williams

Typhoons, earthquakes and torrential downpours have caused large-scale damage throughout Japan, but now the city is using a series of advanced prevention measures to make sure it's disaster-proof

Tokyo will be prepared for the might of earthquakes and typhoons as the city takes pioneering steps to become "disaster-proof."

Japan frequently faces natural disasters with the Great East Japan Earthquake 14 years ago leaving 15,900 dead and 2,520 missing.

Now the Tokyo Metropolitan Government TMG is implementing a series of advanced prevention measures to help the complex metropolis prepare for the worst.

They are not only based on robust infrastructure and earthquake-resistant structural technology, but also establishing world-class rescue teams that can respond quickly in times of need.

As a leader in disaster mitigation and prevention, it is hoped that Tokyo's initiatives will serve as a model case for other countries in a world where risks are increasing.

Here's what they are doing:

Flood Control Reservoirs

TMG has promoted the construction of "regulating reservoirs" where high levels of rainwater can be temporarily stored.

The river channel improvements began in the 1960s to cope with heavy rainfall, which is defined as precipitation of 50 millimeters per hour.

Improvements to reduce flooding generally involve widening the river from downstream.

However, in urban centers with dense housing this takes time, which led to the idea of creating regulating reservoirs to temporarily store the rising water.

As of 2022 there are reservoirs in 28 locations along 12 rivers in Tokyo, including 16 in-ground reservoirs, nine underground vaults, and three underground tunnels.

Combined, they can store approximately 2.63 million cubic meters of water, equivalent to about 8,800 25-meter swimming pools.

The early regulating reservoirs were built in-ground, by digging out large parcels of land along a river, such as a vacant lot or park.

The water that accumulates drains away on its own, and the reservoir can be used as a biotope—a small geographical region that supports its own unique community of organisms—or for other purposes, such as parks or even rice paddies.

With the progress made in installing regulating reservoirs and other facilities, flood damage has steadily decreased.

However, Typhoon Hagibis in 2019 brought record-breaking rainfall that caused seven rivers in Tokyo to overflow and resulted in flood damage, a reminder of the importance of constantly improving the safety infrastructure of the capital.

Earthquake Resistance Technology

Japan has dealt with earthquakes for millennia, but it was the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923, which struck right at the heart of the Tokyo metropolitan area, causing over 100,000 deaths and inflicting enormous damage to lifelines like the electricity and water supply as well as roadways, that led to big changes in technology and legislation.

Since then, Japan has been a world-leader in introducing seismic standards for buildings and significant advances in earthquake-resistant technologies.

These developments are what support Tokyo's high-rise buildings today, such as the capital’s iconic Tokyo Skytree. Built in 2012 using the latest in Japanese building and seismic technology, this skyscraping radio tower can continue transmitting information to affected areas even in the event of a major disaster such as an earthquake.

One element of the tower that plays a major role in its earthquake resistance is the reinforced concrete cylinder in its center, the shinbashira or Core Column.

Measuring eight meters in diameter and 375 meters tall, the column is fixed to the body of the tower with steel up to 125 meters above ground level.

From that point up to the 375-meter point, the shinbashira is not fixed to the tower itself, but is connected by a cylinder with oil inside, called an oil damper. The oil damper acts as a cushion to prevent the core column from hitting the tower body when it shakes.

The steel frame of the tower's main body and core column are designed to sway at different cycles during an earthquake, which damps the swaying of the tower overall, reducing it by up to 50%. It was the first time this sort of damping system had ever been implemented.

The tower body has a truss structure consisting of steel pipe parts, vertically, diagonally, and horizontally, joined in a triangular shape. This structure is carefully calculated and designed so it can withstand the shaking caused by earthquakes and typhoons.

Additionally, the Skytree also functions as an important space for disaster preparedness activities and a disaster prevention stockpile, serving as a crisis management hub for Sumida City.

The 7,000 tons of water stored in the tower for heating and cooling purposes can be utilized in homes and for firefighting purposes in the event of a major disaster.

Hyper Rescue Team

The Fire Rescue Task Forces, also known as Hyper Rescue, were created after the Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake that hit western Japan in 1995.

The quake did not only cause fires but also other complicated rescue situations, including collapsed buildings and roads, that conventional firefighting forces were not equipped to deal with.

It became clear that there was a pressing need for advanced units with specialized knowledge and skills, as well as custom-built heavy machinery and life detectors.

Hyper Rescue HR was established the following year.

Currently divisions are stationed at five of Tokyo’s 10 fire district headquarters, always ready to respond quickly to large-scale disasters that fall within the jurisdiction of the Tokyo Fire Department.

6HR is one such division, headquartered in Adachi City. This district is surrounded by two major rivers, so water rescue is also part of their duties. Unlike other units they have watercraft systems such as jet skis, urethane boats and advanced lifeboats which can hold 20 people and be used to rescue people in wheelchairs.

The unit is also equipped with highly advanced rescue equipment such as underground sound detectors and electromagnetic life detectors, as well as heavy machinery that typical fire stations do not have.

6HR has been dispatched to deal with disasters such as the Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011, the torrential rain in the Kanto and Tohoku regions in 2015, and the Noto Peninsula Earthquake in 2024.

Protecting Tokyo

The Port of Tokyo is an international trading port that serves as a foundation for the industry and everyday lives of the 40 million people who live and work in the city.

But it is also located on the furthest end of Tokyo Bay, where the connection to the sea combined with the shallow bay waters make the area particularly vulnerable to phenomena like storm surges. This is important, as roughly 20% of the 23 wards of Tokyo—approximately 124 square kilometers, housing 1.5 million Tokyo residents—consists of "zero-meter zones" that fall below sea level at high tide.

The Port of Tokyo’s coastal protection facilities—such as floodgates, inland locks, seawalls, and pump stations—continue to be built around low-lying areas to protect the lives and property of Tokyo residents.

The TMG has established the TOKYO Resilience Project in order to prepare against five major potential disasters—storm and flood damage, earthquakes, ash fall from volcanic eruptions, power/telecommunication disruptions, and infectious disease.

Through this 15 trillion yen project, the city is also promoting its safety-minded urban development to the wider world.

urn:contentItem:6G15-V0J3-RV01-40BH-00000-00Japan Power & Renewables Forecast Scenario2025-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:23:08ZLexisNexisJapan Power & Renewables Forecast Scenario

Japan's power generation is projected to grow modestly at an annual rate of 0.7% from 2025 to 2034. The Seventh Strategic Energy Plan introduces upside risks for coal due to contradictions between its fossil fuel strategy and ambitious renewable targets. Despite a previous post-Fukushima stance, nuclear power is expected to increase from 10.2% of the generation mix in 2025 to 13.9% by 2034, as the government aims to maximise nuclear usage. In February 2025, Japan's Seventh Strategic Energy Plan (SEP) was released, with an increased self-development ratio - Japanese companies' control over oil and natural gas imports - to 50% by 2030 and 60% by 2040, encouraging Japanese companies to invest in overseas fossil fuel development for supply certainty. In addition, the Seventh SEP lacks detailed targets for thermal energy sources, unlike the previous Sixth SEP which specifies individual targets for coal, oil and gas. We believe this absence of clarity could delay the coal phase-out. Overall, this has led us to revise our thermal capacity forecasts upwards, expected to remain approximately at the same level for 2024 and 2034, at about 177GW.

In April 2025, Japan's second long-term decarbonisation auction (LTDA) awarded four LNG-fired power plants totalling 1.3GW, or 21% of the awarded capacity. This highlights their importance as transitional assets within Japan's broader capacity market strategy.

In April 2025, Hokuriku Electric Power Company announced plans to construct a new 600MW LNG-fired unit at its Toyama Shinko Thermal Power Station located in Imizu City, Toyama Prefecture, Japan. This unit is intended to replace two ageing thermal power units: a 250MW coal-fired unit and a 240MW oil-fired unit that is currently idled.

Structural TrendsJapan is heavily reliant on conventional thermal power generation for its power supply, relying on it for more than 60% of its power generation needs. Over the long term, we believe that climate commitments will become the focus of Japan’s power market, with coal- and oil-fired power plants to be gradually decommissioned. As new gas-fired power plants come online, they will balance out the decommissioning of coal- and oil-fired power capacity for Japan’s net conventional thermal power capacity to remain around 181GW throughout our forecast period to 2034. Conventional Thermal Dominance Will Wane, But Still A Significant Contributor To The MixWe believe that the main cause for the sector’s contraction is the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI)'s decision to phase out 100 coal power plants by 2030, which was announced in August 2020. These 100 power plants are part of 114 power plants that were built before the mid-1990s, and are marked by the government to be ‘inefficient’. While coal-fired power plants are being decommissioned, we believe that there will be an increase in gas-fired power plants, resulting in a slight net decrease in conventional thermal capacity. We further believe that the decommissioned coal power plants will be replaced with newer coal technologies, which will mean that generation capacity will not change much.METI regards coal as an important generation source. We believe that closures will also be met with the implementation of more efficient coal technologies, such as those using ultra-supercritical boilers or integrated coal gasification plants. This means that Japan will not completely phase out coal power generation. Instead, the government has been making continued investments in the research and development of newer, more efficient coal generation technologies. In 2019, the government formed a panel to draft a plan to urge the closure of all coal-fired plants in the long term. This was met with strong opposition from panel members in the business sector, leading to the scrapping of the plan. Japan remains committed to exploring ammonia as a form of thermal power generation source given its suitability to be blended with coal. In November 2022, JERA announced that, together with Mitsui OSK Lines and NYK, it will explore the construction of the world’s largest operations for the transport of ammonia for power plant fuel to reduce Japan’s coal consumption. JERA currently has 26 thermal power plants in Japan and believes that this project will help develop a supply chain for green fuels, mainly ammonia. However, we believe that this might result in the prolonging of operable coal-fired power plants in Japan, as existing plants can be retrofitted to burn ammonia with coal. As a result, we maintain a marginal contraction of conventional thermal power capacity for Japan.Conventional Thermal Dominance Dependent On Market’s Stance On Natural GasJapan's approach to its power generation mix has continued to evolve since the release of its Sixth Strategic Energy Plan 2030 in October 2021. The plan calls for a reduction in gas-fired power generation to contribute to around 20% of 2030’s generation mix. Gas currently contributes about 33% to the power mix, and this new target marks a downward revision of the target set by the previous Abe administration, which pegged the share of gas to fall to 27% in 2030. This stems from the government’s plans to reduce reliance on liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports, which has exacerbated since the Fukushima disaster, as well as to reduce high retail electricity prices for consumers.Since 2021, progress toward these targets has been mixed. The government's updated Seventh SEP in 2025. As of 2024, thermal generation still accounts for 65% of Japan's power mix. Recognising these hurdles, the government has extended its timeline for achieving a 40-50% share for renewables by 2040 instead. Thermal power is targeted to contribute to 30-40% of Japan's power mix by 2040, though no breakdown is provided among coal, oil and gas, which stands in contrast to the individual targets provided for each renewable source and the previous Sixth SEP's individual breakdown for thermal sources. We expect that this absence of clarity could delay the coal phase-out, potentially increasing coal's share in the energy mix and posing upside risks to our coal forecast.In addition, the Seventh SEP raises the self-development ratio - Japanese companies' control over oil and natural gas imports - to 50% by 2030 and 60% by 2040, encouraging investment in overseas fossil fuel development for supply certainty rather than prioritising domestic renewable sources for energy resilience. This poses upside risk to the thermal sector as a whole, at the expense of renewables growth.Japan remains a key player in the global LNG market, with sustained demand projected over the next decade. However, the expiration of many contracts between 2026 and 2033, particularly those with Russia, introduces uncertainty in the future LNG procurement in Japan. We expect increasing diversification of gas suppliers and a shift away from gas-fired power generation. In July 2022, Russia seized control of the Sakhalin-2 gas and oil project, which is partly owned by Shell, Mitsui and Mitsubishi. Despite the transfer of operations to a new Russian firm in August 2022, Mitsui and Mitsubishi continued their investment due to Japan's energy crisis. With Japan sourcing nearly 10% of its LNG imports from Sakhalin-2 and on the back of upwards revision to our forecasts for coal and nuclear generation, we have revised our gas generation forecast downwards. Japan's nuclear energy policy has evolved significantly since the Fukushima disaster in 2011. By 2022, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) had adopted a policy of 'maximum use' of nuclear energy, extending the operational lifespans of existing reactors and lifting bans on new reactor construction in early 2023 to meet rising electricity demands, particularly from data centres. The Seventh SEP targets 20% of nuclear power in the country's power mix by 2030 and 2040. However, due to the lead time required for safety checks, which limits the technically feasible pace of restarts, we expect the share of nuclear to only reach between 12-13% in 2030.

In April 2025, Japan’s second long-term decarbonisation auction (LTDA) awarded 6.3GW across 38 projects, representing 47% of the 13.6GW total bid capacity. Approximately half of the awarded capacity included three nuclear power plants: Japan Atomic Power Company’s Tokai Unit 2, Hokkaido Electric Power’s Tomari Unit 3, and TEPCO’s Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Unit 6.

In April 2025, Japan's Nuclear Regulation Authority gave regulatory approval for Unit 3 of the Tomari nuclear power plant for its restart, after a necessary evaluation on safety standards. The Tomari plant, located on Hokkaido island, includes two 550MWe and one 912MWe pressurised water reactors, all of which have been offline since 2012. This marks the first such regulatory clearance for reactor restart since 2021 and is a significant step towards resuming operations, pending formal adoption and local government consent.

It used to account for slightly more than 25% of the generation mix in 2010 but dropped to about 6% by the end of 2022. However, recent developments have shown a marked increase in nuclear output, with a 5.6% rise in 2024 reaching about 88TWh. Over the next decade, nuclear power generation will increase to 135.3TWh in 2034, at an annual average of 4.3%. This growth is attributed to the restart of 14 nuclear units, including Onagawa-2 and Shimane-2, reflecting Japan's efforts to enhance nuclear capacity and diversify its energy sources. The strategic restart of these reactors, supported by a legislative framework allowing for operation beyond 60 years with necessary safety upgrades, indicates a robust policy direction aimed at stabilising the energy supply and reducing Japan’s reliance on imported fuels for power generation while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.While we expect further support for nuclear power to take shape in the coming quarters, as electricity price and energy security concerns grow, there has been some progress in gaining more approvals for the restarting of more nuclear power plants in the latter half of this decade. We have included Tokai-2 in our forecast for 2026-2027, Tomari-3 in 2027 and Unit 6 of the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant in 2029. The Onagawa-2 nuclear reactor came online in October 2024. Due to the high cost of reactor restarts and regulatory and safety concerns, we expect reactor restarts to only pick up at the end of this decade and into the 2030s.The ruling LDP coalition lost its majority in the lower house elections in October 2024, which will make policymaking challenging and could lead to increased barriers for nuclear restarts. While the LDP and pro-business allies support nuclear restarts and next-generation technologies, opposition parties like the Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan favour limiting nuclear reliance. The Japanese Communist Party and the Social Democratic Party advocate for a complete phase-out in favour of renewables. This political split highlights the ongoing debate as Japan balances energy security, decarbonisation and public safety concerns. As a result of these challenges and strict Nuclear Regulation Authority (NRA) regulations imposed on nuclear power plants, we believe nuclear reactor restarts will continue to face consistent delays to their restart dates.Japan has two new nuclear reactors under construction: the 1.4GW Ohma nuclear power plant and the 1.4GW Shimane 3 nuclear reactor. Both reactors have been under construction since 2011 and 2012 respectively, with consistent delays to their commissioning date. We remain cautious on whether they will come online, as Japan devotes resources to nuclear power plant restarts. We expect Japan’s operable nuclear power capacity to remain at about 31GW over the coming 10 years. This represents the total capacity of Japan’s existing 33 nuclear reactors. Currently, 10 of the 33 reactors are approved by the NRA to generate electricity. The statuses of these 10 reactors can be found in the table at the end of this section. Limited Progress For Nuclear Reactor Restarts In JapanJapan - Nuclear Power Reactors By Status Source: FEPC, EIA, BMI Intensified Push For Nuclear Power Plant Restarts Presents An Upside RiskJapan is set to maximise its reliance on nuclear power according to its seventh strategic energy plan (SEP), marking a shift from its post-Fukushima efforts to reduce nuclear dependency. The plan aims for nuclear power to contribute about 20% of Japan's energy output by 2040. In order to decrease its dependence on gas power generation, Japan has acknowledged the need to speed up the restarting of nuclear power plants, presenting upside risks to our conservative nuclear generation forecast. In May 2022, former prime minister Fumio Kishida announced that Japan was actively looking to diversify its power mix away from gas power generation, largely from growing nuclear power generation. The rising oil and gas prices have resulted in calls for nuclear power plant restarts in Japan to bring down rising electricity prices. The restart of Takahama 1 and 2 nuclear reactors in 2023 resulted in strong nuclear power generation growth for that year, which we estimate was more than 10TWh. Onagawa 2 is another nuclear power reactor included in our short-term forecast, having come online in October 2024. These plants, which have passed the stringent safety checks, will be retrofitted with anti-terrorism mechanisms and receive the appropriate regulatory approvals. Aside from these plants, we expect limited growth in Japan’s nuclear power sector for the longer term, although we see upside risks to this forecast if Japan successfully diversifies its generation mix.In February 2023, Japan's government formally introduced a major policy for the nuclear power sector by extending the operation time for nuclear power plants. The previously set nominal operating period, introduced in July 2013, was 40 years. Under the former policy, extensions were granted up to a maximum of 20 years, dependent on safety requirements. The operating period has since been extended to 60 years (not including closure periods for maintenance and refuelling), following the NRA’s approval on December 21 2022. Operators of reactors in use for 30 years or longer must formulate a long-term reactor management plan and gain approval from the regulator at least once every 10 years if they are to continue to operate. The Takahama reactors 1 and 2 were the first to be granted a licence extension of more than 40 years after the regulation revision in February 2023, with Takahama 1 restarting in 2023.In July 2023, Japan announced that it is considering a financing scheme to aid in the development of safety measures for dormant nuclear reactors. These reactors are operable but have been brought offline after the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Currently, owners and operators are apprehensive about restarting these nuclear power plants due to the costs of upgrading the plants with stringent safety and operational checks. In light of this, METI proposed to include existing nuclear power plants in the January 2024 auction programme, which currently only encompasses new renewable and nuclear power projects. However, given the limited nuclear reactor restart approvals in Japan and companies reluctant to apply for approvals, we believe that the inclusion, if approved, will only provide a minor upside for the nuclear power sector. Hydropower Forecasts Structural TrendsWe believe that there will be limited developments in the hydropower sector, although the sector will continue to contribute 8-9% to the overall power mix throughout our forecast period to 2034. While limited, most of the development will be pumped hydropower projects, with the Kannagawa hydropower plant being one of the largest such plants globally in development.Japan’s hydropower capacity will remain at about 23GW over the coming years, while pumped hydropower capacity will increase from about 27GW in 2024 to about 31.6GW in 2034. Pumped hydropower developments will be supported by increasing efforts to balance the grid as Japan introduces more intermittent renewables to the power mix. Growth for conventional hydropower plants will mainly be due to small hydropower plants. However, the cost to generate electricity from such plants is much higher than large-scale hydropower plants and other power types, resulting in a limited overall growth for hydropower capacity. In April 2025, Japan’s second long-term decarbonisation auction (LTDA) awarded 6.3GW across 38 projects, representing 47% of the 13.6GW total bid capacity. Battery storage accounted for 1.4GW, or 22% of the awarded capacity, 25% higher than the first LTDA. Even so, BESS was the most oversubscribed technology, with only 20% of the bid capacity awarded. Notable developers include Taiwan's HD Renewable Energy, which has been awarded 300MW across five projects, as well as an energy storage platform backed by Stonepeak/CHC with 348MW across five projects.

In December 2024, the capacities of applications for connection assessment and grid connection contracts for grid-scale storage batteries in the nation reached approximately 95GW and 8GW, respectively. This represents an approximate eightfold increase compared to the data from the end of May 2023, indicating a significant surge in interest and investment in grid-scale storage solutions.

Structural TrendsBESS have been on the rise in Japan, with renewable power projects planned with an associated facility. Japan also has ambitions to expand its battery manufacturing sector, reaching around 20% global market share by 2030. The industry ministry has announced that it needs more than USD24.0bn in public and private sector investment for batteries of electric vehicles and energy storage. The market's focus on solid-state batteries highlights its commitment to leading the next generation of energy storage solutions. These batteries promise higher energy density and enhanced safety compared to traditional lithium-ion variants. Substantial subsidies, over USD660mn allocated in 2024, are facilitating the commercialisation of solid-state batteries by 2030, with companies like Toyota spearheading the efforts. Toyota's strategic plan to commence mass production by 2027 or 2028, along with Japan's commanding 36% share of global solid-state battery patents, underscores the market's innovative capacity and potential market leadership. We expect the effects of an expanding battery manufacturing industry to cascade into the market’s ability to develop BESS over the next decade. There is currently about 170MW of grid-connected BESS capacity in Japan, coming from Pacifico Energy’s BESS project. We expect this to expand robustly, mainly in the latter half of our forecast period, to about 4,045MW by 2034.  Similarly, as Japan continues to refine its feed-in-premium (FiP) scheme, the ability of generators to increase electricity supply during peak hours using BESS will likely drive further growth in the market as well. In April 2023, METI announced plans to launch a new auction scheme for battery storage facilities. This will allow battery storage facilities of at least 10MW to be connected to the grid and permit its operators to sell electricity on the Japanese Electric Power Exchange or engage in power purchase agreements. METI started the auction in January 2024, with expressions of interest from companies to pre-register from October 2023. As of May 2024, the government announced that it has allocated about 1.1GW of BESS capacity was allocated across 30 projects, through the Long-Term Decarbonisation Power Source Auction. The auction was carried out by the Organisation for Cross-regional Coordination of Transmission Operators (OCCTO), which governs auctions launched for renewable power types, such as solar and wind. We believe that this will encourage the growth of the battery storage sector in Japan, supporting more growth in renewables as the market grapples with integrating intermittent renewables into the grid. As part of the auction, there was 577MW of pumped hydropower storage up for bidding, bringing the total power storage capacity on offer to about 1GW. From October 2025, an initial investment support scheme will be introduced to accelerate rooftop PV power generation deployment. PV systems under 10kW will receive 24 yen/kWh for up to four years and 8.3 yen/kWh for 5-10 years. Rooftop PV systems of 10kW or more will receive 19 yen/kWh for up to five years and 8.3 yen/kWh for 6-20 years.

In April 2025, Trina Solar ISBU announced a 20-year power purchase agreement (PPA) with Equinix for a 30MW solar power plant in Yufutsu Abira, Hokkaido, Japan. This plant is expected to generate approximately 36GWh of electricity annually starting from the third quarter of 2028.

In June 2025, Japanese utility J-POWER announced the commercial operation of the 29.99MW Kitakyushu Hibikinada Solar Power Station in Fukuoka Prefecture.

 Structural TrendsJapan experienced strong solar capacity growth historically, as a result of a strong solar project pipeline that benefitted from the generous FiT support scheme. Net solar capacity growth will slow from 2025 to 2034, averaging an annual growth rate of 4.1%, compared to the previous decade at 15.2%, as auctions and PPAs, rather than FiTs, become the main driver of large-scale solar capacity growth. This policy shift is the result of the government's efforts to ensure price competitiveness for new projects through a bidding system. An auction system means that the government can identify solar project areas that can be easily integrated into the grid before developing them.METI held its first solar power auction in November 2017. By implementing auctions, the government aims to gain greater control over the sector’s growth, reduce the risk of curtailments and achieve cost savings for Japan’s public finances relative to using FiTs across all solar power projects. Unlike fixed FiTs, where it is up to the regulator to set a cost-based purchase price, auctions drive down tariffs paid by the government, as companies are incentivised to submit the lowest bid possible to win contracts.Overall Uptake For Renewable Power Auctions Improving, Companies Show Waning Interest For Solar Initially, Japan struggled to manage the transition to an auctions system, with lower-than-expected capacity being awarded and limited reduction in electricity costs. In the first three auctions, bids submitted were over USD130/MWh, which is higher than other solar power markets. In the fourth and fifth auctions (both held in 2019) bids were lowered, to an average of USD116/MWh, which is still high. This is attributed to significant security deposit requirements, high labour costs, limitations to grid capacity availability and difficulties in acquiring suitable land. Biomass projects faced similar challenges, although they typically require lesser land requirements than solar. In April 2022, FiP system took effect, superseding the FiT system for certain renewable power projects above 1MW in capacity. This will allow renewable power producers to sell electricity at a premium price above the wholesale spot market. Most sub-sectors have faced FiT cuts in recent years, except for geothermal, offshore wind and small-scale renewables generation. This highlights Japan's push to support these sub-sectors in particular. In parallel, the transition from the FiT system to the FiP system has reshaped Japan's solar PV market. The FiP system introduces a market-driven approach, adding a premium to market prices rather than offering fixed purchase prices, thereby fostering competition and innovation while reducing consumer costs. As of early 2024, the FiP system had certified 1,507MW across 1,036 projects, with solar power accounting for 518MW across 955 projects. This shift has particularly promoted low-voltage solar projects for business use, expanding the market's reach.In June 2022 and August 2022, the OCCTO announced solar PV project tender results for the 12th and 13th tenders. From January 2022 to August 2022, Japan experienced an increase in solar PV tenders.The 12th tender, which is a solar PV auction scheme, was Japan’s first programme that awarded either FiTs or FiPs. FiPs were awarded to projects above the capacity of 1MW, while FiTs were awarded for projects ranging in capacity from 250.0kW to 1.0MW. Within the 12th tender, FiPs were set at JPY9.9/kWh (USD0.0703) while FiTs had the lowest bid of JPY9.80/kWh (USD0.0698). These prices are much lower than that awarded in the first auction, which was USD0.13/kWh. This indicates that the scheme is starting to drive prices down, which was the aim of the government in phasing out the FiT scheme. On March 10, 2023, OCCTO released the results of its 15th solar auction for the FiP and FiT programmes. Both programmes saw bids lower than the rate cap on offer, which indicates that there is an ongoing trend of solar prices dropping in Japan. This has continued on for the subsequent auctions, with the latest 22nd solar auction allocating 56.4MW of solar PV capacity with the lowest bid at JPY7.5/kWh (USD0.049/kWh). The average final price was JPY8.17/kWh. In comparison to previous auctions, this auction's lowest bid is one of the lowest recorded, indicating competitive pricing and potential cost reductions in Japan's solar market. In prior auctions, the average final prices ranged from JPY4.5 to JPY9.73/kWh. In March 2025, J-Power and KDDI signed a 20-year virtual Power Purchase Agreement (vPPA) to develop a 51.5MW onshore wind farm in Kaminokuni-cho, Hokkaido, Japan. The wind farm is expected to begin commercial operations in September 2028.

In April 2025, Japan’s largest onshore wind farm with a capacity of 147MW began operations, located in the Abukuma area of Fukushima.

In May 2025, Japan announced plans to enhance its offshore wind sector to achieve 45GW of capacity by 2040 amid global project slowdowns. This initiative aims to reduce reliance on imported coal and gas, cut carbon emissions and bolster national security. Industry players are pushing for extended project durations and clearer cabotage laws, with discussions about moving from a 'feed-in tariff' to a 'feed-in premium' system to benefit from market prices. Mitsubishi, a key player in Japan's offshore wind sector, is experiencing delays and is monitoring potential rule changes. Despite these challenges, Japan continues to attract foreign interest, with companies like RWE, Iberdrola and BP participating in future auctions.

 Structural TrendsWe remain cautious about Japan's wind power growth over the coming decade. Our conservative outlook is attributed to surging costs that have resulted in construction delays, as well as the falling costs of solar, reducing the competitiveness of wind in comparison. By 2030, wind power generation is expected to contribute less than 2% of Japan's total power generation, aligning with the government's target of 1.7% by that year. About 74% of this generation in 2030 will come from onshore wind; however, we expect offshore wind’s share to increase in the coming years due to favourable policies. Looking forward, Japan's wind power capacity is expected to grow at an average annual rate of 9%, increasing from 6.3GW in 2025 to 13.7GW by 2034. While challenges such as project delays and financial risks remain, the strategic focus on offshore wind, supported by robust international collaborations and government policies, positions Japan to significantly enhance its renewable energy portfolio.There is a significant upside risk to the wind power sector as the government is targeting 10GW of offshore wind development by 2030. In November 2022, METI announced that it plans to resume offshore wind power auctions in December 2022. With revised rules for offshore wind for operators, METI expects this to encourage more operators to be involved in the development of the market’s offshore wind power sector. METI is aiming to select operators for offshore wind power projects across four newly designated zones, capable of housing about 1GW of offshore wind power capacity. While there are still restrictions on how much one consortium or company can win in an auction (the limit is currently at 1.0GW), hindering the attractiveness of auctions for companies, we believe that the resumption of offshore wind power auctions presents upside risks for the sector. As a result, we have revised up our forecasts for offshore wind power capacity and generation.Location And Cost Hurdles For Onshore Wind, Risks AlleviatingJapan’s wind power strategy envisions robust onshore wind power capacity growth. However, the development of onshore wind is limited by the lack of land close to power demand centres. Suitable land areas for onshore wind are usually less populated and mountainous. These areas usually have high wind speeds but have poor access to the national grid. While transmission and distribution (T&D) investments will rise, we expect most of it to focus on integrating existing solar farms, instead of onshore wind farms.The first onshore wind power auction, launched in November 2021, awarded a total of 936.0MW in capacity across 32 bids, out of 1,000MW offered. The range of awarded bids was from JPY14.98/kWh to JPY17.00/kWh. These prices were much higher than that observed in the table above for solar power auctions.The results of the second onshore wind power auction, released on November 4 2022, offered a much-needed lift for the sector with about 1,290MW of the allocated 1,300MW for the auction being awarded. Bid prices were slightly lower than that of the first auction, with the minimum successful bid price being JPY14.80/kWh while the maximum is JPY16.00/kWh.As for the third auction, there was 1,000MW of onshore wind capacity on offer. The auction was oversubscribed, with bids totalling about 1,414MW in capacity. However, there was an underwhelming response for the offshore wind power sector. For the 190MW on offer there was only one plan of 165MW that was eligible, but the company did not submit a bid. We highlight that this seems separate from the 1,800MW auction that the government launched in June 2023 under METI. The same underwhelming response was experienced for the biomass power auction, which saw no bids for 120MW on offer. We believe that onshore wind and solar remain the top renewables types for the short term, which is evidenced by the market’s response to these auctions.Increasing Upside For Nascent Offshore Wind Given the challenges for onshore wind, Japan has pivoted to developing the offshore wind sub-sector. The government targets 10GW and 30-45GW offshore wind capacity by 2030 and 2040 respectively. With Japan’s major power demand cities located near coasts, developers can develop offshore wind power farms closer to them. Japan estimates offshore wind power potential over 600GW, supporting their ambitious offshore wind capacity targets for 2030 and 2040.We believe that this focus on offshore wind presents an upside risk to our forecasts. Japan has launched a policy bill for offshore wind, which sets regulations and a framework to boost offshore wind development across 30 locations by 2030. Japan launched its first offshore wind tender in June 2020, for the Goto project near Nagasaki. The government further announced that it will launch auctions for four additional offshore wind sites: Noshiro; Yurihonjo North; Yurihonjo South, in the Akita prefectures; and Choshi, in the Tokyo Prefecture. In December 2021, the government awarded a consortium consisting of Mitsubishi Corporation, Mitsubishi Corporation Energy Solutions and C-Tech Corporation as operators for three wind power projects in Akita and Chiba. The wind farm in Chiba will have a capacity of 391.0MW, while the two wind farms in Akita will have 479.0MW and 819.0MW respectively. Venti Japan will join the consortium for the 819MW wind power project. The companies expect the wind farms to come online between September 2028 and December 2030.In June 2023, Japan wrapped up its bidding applications for its second offshore wind auction. The auction offered a total of 1,800MW of offshore wind power capacity across four areas, garnering interest from major companies such as Itochu and Tokyo Gas. In December 2023, METI and MLIT announced that three Japanese consortiums had won bids for projects in Akita, Niigata, and Nagasaki Prefectures. In the Akita Prefecture, a consortium including JERA will build 21 wind turbines with a total capacity of 315MW off the coasts of Oga, Katagami, and Akita Cities. The project is expected to be operational by June 2028 at a bid price of JPY3.0/kWh. In the Niigata Prefecture, a consortium comprising Mitsui, RWE Offshore Japan and Osaka Gas will construct 38 turbines with a total capacity of 684MW, also at JPY3.0/kWh, with operations starting by June 2029. In the Nagasaki Prefecture, Sumitomo Corp. and Tokyo Electric Renewable Power will develop 28 turbines totalling 420MW. The bid price is JPY22.2/kWh, with operations commencing in August 2029. The higher cost is attributed to the hard bedrock in the area.In December 2024, METI and MLIT revealed the outcomes of Japan’s offshore wind 'Round 3' auction. The successful bidders included the Tsugaru Offshore Energy Consortium for the Sea of Japan (South), Aomori project with a capacity of 615MW, and the Yamagata Yuza Offshore Wind LLC for the Yuza, Yamagata project with a capacity of 450MW. Both projects are slated to begin commercial operations by June 2030, offering power at JPY3.0/kWh. Our forecasts show that offshore wind power growth will be weighted towards 2027 and beyond, which these recent developments are in line with, considering the time taken to construct and commission offshore wind power projects after companies are awarded project areas.Cost, Scaling And Climate Issues To Weigh On Offshore Wind GrowthDespite the growing momentum for offshore wind in Japan, there is caution in revising forecasts upward due to previous setbacks in the sector. Legislation from 2018 aimed to establish wind energy development zones to address location challenges, particularly opposition from fisheries and shipping industries. This law emphasises selecting bid winners based on price and development plans, with MHI Vestas as a preferred bidder for the 220MW Hibikinada project in 2019. However, we note that offshore wind companies, like Orsted, faced significant financial setbacks in 2023 and 2024 due to rising construction costs, higher interest rates, and supply chain issues since increased generation costs after auction applications could not be reflected in electricity prices.Offshore wind in Japan is currently more costly than other energy sources like solar, partly due to insufficient supply chains and lengthy environmental assessments, which can take up to five years. Additionally, Japan faces unique challenges such as typhoons and tsunamis. With deep waters making fixed-bottom wind projects costly, there is a shift towards floating offshore wind technology, which offers flexibility and higher wind speed access. This has led to ambitious targets of 4.0GW of floating wind by 2030 and 18.0GW by 2050, tapping into deeper waters where 80% of potential sites are over 100m deep.Japan's push for floating wind power also faces challenges due to deep waters, increasing costs for fixed-bottom turbines. While floating wind could offer solutions, it's currently limited to pilot projects, supporting a cautious outlook for growth. The technology needs economies of scale, reduced equipment costs, and expertise development to become commercially viable. Floating wind is costlier than fixed bottom, requiring significant government support, which is limited in Japan. Past experiences with solar and biomass sectors, where initial incentives led to overwhelming capacity and subsequent support reductions, suggest conservative government backing for wind. Japan's focus on reducing electricity costs constrains its ability to offer subsidies akin to those in the solar and biomass sectors.To help curb some of these challenges, in 2024, the Japanese government revised its rules for offshore wind power auctions in response to global sector challenges such as delays and increased costs due to tight supply chains and inflation. After consultations since September 2024, the industry and land ministries have implemented changes, including an electricity price adjustment scheme and higher deposit requirements to manage project delays. Similarly, Japan's well-developed labour market and strategic location could help it lead in floating offshore wind development. This could allow Japanese firms to gain a first-mover advantage in the global wind market, compensating for their late entry into fixed-bottom technology. Over time, developing expertise in floating wind could position Japanese companies competitively in the offshore wind sector globally. Other Non-Hydropower Renewables Forecasts Structural TrendsJapan remains at a crossroads in its controversial use of burning forest biomass to make electricity. While the government and private sector’s understanding of the fuel’s harmful environmental and climate impacts is growing, biomass power plants long in the pipeline continue to come online, requiring ever-greater volumes of imported wood pellets from primary forests in Canada or plantations in Vietnam.Using forest biomass for electricity generation took off in Japan in 2012, when the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry introduced an FiT with 20-year fixed rates to support renewable energy projects. However, despite push back form forest advocates and environmentalists on the negative climate impacts of using wood pellets for biomass power generation, we highlight that the government’s feed-in tariff scheme, which has been tweaked but not cancelled, continues to incentivise these projects. Over the next decade, we expect biomass capacity to increase from 6.1GW in 2025 to 7.0GW by 2034, with generation remaining relatively constant at 37-39TWh over this period. With operators of existing biomass power plants keeping their plants running in order to pay back construction bank loans, and the government’s, albeit limited, continued support for the power source in an aim to reach its energy transition goals. Electricity Generation And Power Generating CapacityElectricity ConsumptionJapan's long-term electricity demand is projected to grow moderately, driven by a combination of factors that highlight the need for increased capacity and resilience. Our forecasts indicate a modest annual growth rate of approximately 0.6% in electricity consumption, rising from 878.0TWh in 2025 to about 923TWh by 2034. This growth reflects not only the burgeoning need for energy in emerging technologies and sectors, but also the resilience of Japan's industrial demand despite demographic challenges.As a global leader in manufacturing, Japan's industrial sector has historically been the largest consumer of electricity, largely due to its substantial production of automobiles, consumer electronics, and computers. This trend is expected to persist, with manufacturing continuing to dominate energy consumption. However, Japan faces a unique challenge: population decline, and urbanisation trends are set to influence the electricity market significantly. Forecasts indicate a contraction in the urban population by an annual average of -0.50% from 2025 to 2034, with the total population expected to decrease by 0.6%, from approximately 123mn in 2025 to just over 115mn by 2034. This demographic shift could potentially moderate overall electricity demand growth, as fewer people may translate into reduced residential electricity usage.The rise of electric vehicles (EVs) presents a new dimension to electricity demand. Our Autos team projections suggest that EV sales in Japan will increase by about 140% between 2025 and 2034, with an annual average growth rate of 17%, reaching about 10% of total vehicle sales by the end of the decade. This surge is expected to drive a considerable increase in electricity consumption, as the transport sector transitions from fossil fuels to electric power.The market’s recent power supply challenges, exacerbated by the increase in early 2025 due to colder temperatures, have also underscored the urgency of expanding reserve margins to ensure grid stability. Additionally, the rapid expansion of AI and data centre operations, is set to further boost electricity consumption over the next decade. However, this rising demand will be tempered by advancements in energy efficiency and substantial investments in modernising the grid. Enhanced transmission infrastructure and smart grid technologies are expected to optimise energy use, partially offsetting the overall increase in consumption and helping Japan transition to a more sustainable and reliable power system. In line with this, Japan's 10 regional utility companies and the government are accelerating the development of smart metres to help consumers monitor and moderate consumption. Smart meters facilitate two-way communication between consumers and generators, allowing consumers to monitor consumption and electricity prices at set time intervals. This keeps households aware of their power consumption and encourages them to reduce bills by reducing or shifting consumption from peak periods to off-peak periods.As retail electricity prices increase, we believe that residential, commercial and industrial consumers will develop on-site solar capacity and shift towards self-generation. Consumers can also supply surplus generation back into the grid, reducing their reliance on retail electricity. This will likely result in a drop in on-grid power consumption.  Total Power Generation And Consumption To Stagnate Over The Coming 10 Years Japan - Total Power Generation & Net Power Consumption, TWh (2000-2034) e/f = BMI estimate/forecast. Source: METI, EIA, local sources, BMI Transmission And Distribution, Imports And Exports Structural TrendsJapan’s electricity grid is well maintained and efficient, with T&D set to average about 4.2% of the total generation output over 2025-2034. This is lower than larger and more mature markets, reflecting the market’s strong capability to curb losses, mainly through technological developments and the location of power plants near demand centres. Distribution losses in Japan are among the lowest in developed markets, comparable with other densely populated, often smaller markets.The 10 main utility companies, which own and operate all high-voltage transmission lines, were historically required to maintain self-sufficiency in each of their respective localities. This meant that interconnections between the 10 supply areas were weak and mainly intended for operational system security purposes. This acted as a barrier to entry for independent power producers as they were unable to secure grid connections and faced high grid charges. In 2015, the government established OCCTO, an independent institution to oversee an efficient T&D network across Japan, which fully deregulated the retail sector in April 2016. The government also laid out the 2013 Energy Reform Plan, which required companies to split their T&D operations from the electricity generation and retail businesses.Japan’s national grid remains isolated from other markets due to geographical constraints. There is also no construction of cross-border power lines planned to connect the market to regional peers.Grid Expansion Limited, Upgrades To Existing Infrastructure Under WayJapan's transmission system is divided into the northern system, with 50Hz, and the southern system, with 60Hz. The two frequency areas are currently interconnected with three frequency converters. Overall, Japan's transmission system consists of 14,100km of 500kV transmission lines, 16,000km of 275kV cable, 11,000km of lines capable of transmitting 187-220kV and more than 30,000km of 110-154kV lines. There is around 95,000km of cabling capable of carrying 77kV or lower amounts. We expect limited growth in the transmission system, as Japan has a subdued growth in electricity demand and the current grid coverage extends to all major power demand centres.We expect the government to upgrade the power grid to a next-generation T&D network. This will deal with structural issues, such as a decline in power demand from changing population demographics, cross-regional electricity trading, the integration of intermittent renewable power sources, the expansion of distributed energy resources and environmental changes. Tokyo Electric Power has announced plans to invest JPY470bn (USD3.25bn) by financial year 2027 to expand its power grid to meet growing electricity demand for AI data centres. The Japanese utility giant also plans to triple its investment in power grid infrastructure in the next five years.Government support to strengthen Japan’s grid resilience was further reaffirmed recently after a series of natural disasters. Following Typhoon Hagibis and Typhoon Faxai, which damaged power grids and caused major power outages, the government plans to encourage investment in storage systems. The government believes that this will be a key demand response technology. METI plans to spend JPY7.5bn (USD68.0mn) to promote such purchases, while the Ministry of Environment plans to create a financial aid programme, which will assist in independent community-based systems that will incorporate renewable energy, storage systems and transmission grids. urn:contentItem:643D-S041-JDPF-B2PT-00000-00Fraser Brown: Scotland’s last clash with Japan had everything - including Typhoon Hagibis2021-11-17T00:00:00Z2025-09-09T21:23:07ZLexisNexisRUGBY UNIONSCOTLAND RUGBY UNIONFraser Brown: Scotland’s last clash with Japan had everything - including Typhoon HagibisFraser Brown

Scotland’s last meeting with Japan was one of the most unbelievable games I’ve been involved in, and not just because of the build-up, although that was like nothing I have ever experienced before.

The threat of Typhoon Hagibis loomed over the fixture and ended up causing widespread destruction in Japan and the deaths of at least 98 people. Three matches at the 2019 Rugby World Cup were cancelled and Scotland’s final group match against the hosts in Yokohama was under threat.

Even at breakfast on the morning of the game most of us were still unsure as to whether it would go ahead. Even more uncertain were the arrangements if the game was called off; could it be played the following day, or would it be cancelled and the points shared?

I had no real appreciation what the typhoon would be like. I remember in the evening stepping outside our hotel situated in the middle of Yokohama, a long way away from where the full force was felt, and thinking it like a storm on the west coast of Scotland. I went back inside and into a lift with our forwards coach Danny Wilson and Stuart Yule, our head strength and conditioner, and all of a sudden the lift went black and dropped around five to 10 metres! We were about 40 stories up in a huge skyscraper and it was terrifying. We got out of the lift and the whole building was swaying and you could hear it creaking and shrieking. I know now that all those skyscrapers are built to move in hurricanes and typhoons but it was a very strange sensation.

Despite it all, I actually slept like a baby that night, very unusual before a Test match!

The game got the green light to go ahead and as we made our way to the stadium you couldn’t tell that there had been a typhoon.

They had begun clearing up the damage at about 2am and by the time we’d woken up all the routes to the ground and the stadium itself had been cleared.

Every single fan with a ticket was able to go. It was an unbelievable achievement to get the game on in a packed stadium, a monumental effort and testament to the organisers and the Japanese people.

It was a match-day I will never forget, starting with the anthems.

The Japanese anthem is very solemn and there were around 70,000 people singing it. It was a very strange and humbling experience because of what had happened in the previous 24 hours.

The game itself was played at a ferocious pace. We knew we needed a bonus-point win and in the first half we made a couple of mistakes and Japan capitalised and all of a sudden, we’re going in at half-time chasing the game.

The tempo Japan created in their phase play was incredible but that was how they been playing throughout the tournament. Leading-up to that World Cup the Japanese players had been in camp for something like nine out of the previous 12 months. They were an incredible rugby team but they were also one of the best prepared. Their skill-set was brilliant, their pace was brilliant and the way they pushed the boundaries was brilliant.

Their angles clearing out rucks were questionable and at times they just came straight in at the side but they were clever about it, always removing opposition players and clearing through to create quick ball.

I remember vividly the noise in the last ten minutes. I’d been replaced by Stuart McInally and it had become obvious to the whole stadium that Japan were going to win and go through to the quarter-finals. The sound was like nothing I’ve ever heard before in a stadium. It was incredible.

READ MORE: AB Zondagh thinks Scotland can ‘crack the Da Vinci code’ as new coach gives backing to Finn Russell

Japan won 28-21 and it felt strange after the game. I didn’t think we’d played poorly. There were some bad mistakes, some bad defensive errors but we scored some good tries, particularly in the second half. There was the obvious disappointment not just for the loss to Japan but for the entire tournament, we had massively underperformed and underachieved.

For some guys in that team, they probably knew that was the end of the road for their Scotland careers, whether through retirement or not hitting the heights at the tournament.

Scotland and Japan meet again on Saturday at BT Murrayfield and they are two very different teams to where they were in 2019.

Covid has disrupted Japan’s ability to build on their World Cup success and that is a real shame. Domestic rugby has got going again but it has been very hard for their national team to travel overseas.

They suffered a heavy defeat in Dublin a fortnight ago but that was against a very good Ireland team as we saw at the weekend when they beat the All Blacks.

Japan also played the Wallabies the week before but they’ve had very little meaningful Test rugby since the World Cup because of travel restrictions.

They had a tight game against Portugal last weekend which they won and every week they are together in camp they will improve.

For Scotland, there are some obvious technical improvements that they will have been working on after the South Africa defeat and they will want to see those improvements this weekend but importantly they will want to demonstrate that last week’s underperformance was a one-off.

There will always be matches that you will lose and there will always been disappointment from loses and missed opportunities but from every loss there’s an opportunity for growth, a chance to learn and improve and for Scotland they have a great opportunity to finish the Autumn Nations Series with three wins from four and carry real momentum into one of the competitive Six Nations ever.
